intro: Crambe orientalis var. alutacea, commonly known as the oriental crambe, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring hairy stems and alternate, pinnately lobed leaves. Its flowers are small, yellowish, and arranged in racemes, often blooming in late summer. This variety is notable for its ornamental value and potential as a source of biofuel due to its high oil content.
